Reporter asserts peace plan will not help El Salvador
by Tammy Halevy
Will the Arias peace plan work for El
Salvador? "No," said Chris Norton, a
reporter for the Baltimore Sun, the Christian
Science Monitor, Long Island Newsday, and
the Toronto Daily Mail, who has lived in El
Salvador for the last four years, in a lecture
Saturday evening.
"It's not a very hopeful situation," he said.
"Not many positive changes have occurred,
and worse, no one seems to care."
The peace plan is "a deal between [Costa
Rican President Oscar] Arias and the
Democrats in [the United States] Congress,"
explained Norton. Congress agreed to stop
providing aid to the U.S.-backed Contra
rebels fighting the Nicaraguan government in
exchange for changes in the political system
in Nicaragua.
"El Salvador was left in the shadows," explained Norton, that the plan was not designed specifically for El Salvador.
Norton contended that the plan demands little of El Salvador because "the assumption
is that very little has to happen. . .[They are
perceived to be] living in an emerging
democracy. To some, [the election of
Salvadorean President Jose Napoleon] Duarte

in 1984 showed that positive steps were being taken."
Norton expressed some surprise that Duarte
even accepted the Arias plan. He-argued that
because Duarte "is an agent of U.S. policy,
it was a shock that he signed the plan over
the wishes of the Reagan Administration."
Two explanations explain Duarte's acceptance, according to Norton. First, contended
Norton, El Salvador's president was nervous
about the potential for the Democrats to con(trol U.S. foreign policy in the near future. In
response, Duarte accepted the peace plan in
an attempt to establish conncections with the
Democrats and to distance himself from the
Reagan Administration.
Second, Norton expressed the possibility
that "Duarte saw the plan as a way of framing himself as a peacemaker again," because
"analysis of the plan shows that little is required of the Salvadorans."
The peace plan calls upon El Salvador to
take steps to achieve a cease fire in El
Salvador and to grant amnesty to political
prisoners. According to Norton, Duarte used amnesty to his benefit. "Americas Watch,
the organization which monitors human rights
in this area, called it 'an amnesty for the death
squads,'" he said.

Muller claims current policy
on tenure causes problems
by Brad Handler
and Elizabeth Harrigan
"What was seen as a solution
has NA, ound up causing more problems for the University,"said
University President Steven
Muller in a recent News-Letter interview, in reference to the current policy for granting tenure to
associate professors.
Muller detailed the history and
impetus for changing tenure
policy at Hopkins. Traditionally,
the policy holds that tenure will
not be given until full professorship has been attained.
Muller suggested that, as
recently as twenty years ago,
tenure was not much of an issue
because at that time, a greater
percentage of scholars were being promoted to full professorships. "Now," he said, "people honestly don't know whether
they will get tenure after associate
professorship.
"A couple of years ago, we
were looking at people getting attractive offers of associate professorships with tenure from
other places, " said Muller.
"[We have a feeling that] we are
losing and not attracting people
because we cannot give them
tenure as associate professors."
Muller said that a subcommittee was formed at that time to examine tenure policy at Hopkins.
It modified tenure regulations by
permitting tenure to be given at
the associate professor level in
exceptional cases.
Muller said that the changes
made two years ago did not address the issue properly. "I think
there is a continuing disposition
that there should be some changes
in the [tenure] procedure," he
said, "[but] if you were to ask me
where this will all come out, I
honestly don't know."
The discussion of tenure continued with the issue of mandatory retirement for faculty
members. As of last year, the
federal law regarding mandatory
retirement at age seventy was
changed; under the new law,

mandatory retirement can no
longer be based on age. Universities unsuccessfully attempted to
be exempted from the law;
however, they were given a year
grace period.
Muller said that the issue is
whether Hopkins should use the
exemption. He raised four problems with professors not retiring at age seventy.
The first point was one of expense. "It is not so much a question of paying people,"he said,
but rather the University's continued contribution to employee
benefits for retirement years. The
University contributes more
money for a retirement period
necessarily shortened by continued employment.
Muller raised in his second
point whether professors who
work past age seventy should
continue to keep offices and
laboratory space, which would
suggest conflict with newer
faculty.
Furthermore, said Muller,
"tenure used to be a commitment
until retirement. Now, it's virtually a lifetime commitment."
Finally, Muller suggested that
the issue of tenure could take on
new meaning because it guarantees employment for a long
period of time. "Tenure has
never been an absolute right,
he said. He spoke of the possibility of creating an evaluation
system because "you're going to
make a lifetime commitment to
people and can't dismiss them on
account of age,"he said. Muller
mentioned that another option
might be to hire professors on a
contract basis.
He noted that this policy may
not pose a big problem. "It's an
erroneous assumption to believe
that faculty members will want to
stay here forever," he said.

The Division of Education
of The Johns Hopkins School
of Continuing Studies has
recently taken a step to
strengthen its principals' training program by forming closer
links between Hopkins academics and school principals in
several Maryland school
districts.
"All too often, the perception
is the University professors are
in ivory towers," said Ellen
Elms Notar, coordinator of the
Hopkins Educational Leadership Program. "We need to
have contact with the people we
are in the business of training,
with those who are out there doing this job."
Notar has formed the Principals Advisory Committee,
composed of twelve elementary, middle, and high school
principals from three counties
and Baltimore City. The committee will advise the Division
of Education on how to improve its principals' training
program, bringing to bear their
extensive experience in a
variety of settings to discussions of issues that affect the
principal's performance of his
job.
Research has shown that, of
all the key players in primary
and secondary education, the
school principal plays the
crucial role in determining the
quality of education in school
districts nationwide.
Consequently, the issue of
educational leadership—how

The Future of Tenure
The issue of tenure is a delicate, and above all,
complex one. It reflects the university's commitment to its immeasurably valuable recourse: the
faculty.
The Academic Council of the Homewood Schools
at present is attempting to redefine policy towards
granting tenure to associate professors. Two years
ago, the Council changed policy from not giving
associate professors tenure to giving it in "...exceptional circumstances where it is in the compelling interest of the University to do so..." The Council feels this policy is too vaguely worded to adequately guide them in tenure decisions.
The disposition to change policy two years ago
was motivated by a perception that associate professors were being lured to other institutions which
were offering associate professorships with tenure.
Recognizing certain problems with regualarly offering tenure to associate professors, they struck
upon the "exceptional circumstance" compromise.
The new policy, as Muller described "has caused more problems than it has solved." Proposals
to rectify the situation include granting tenure to
associate professors as a separate process from promotion to the rank of associate professor, and
regualarly granting associate profesoors tenure except in some circumstances.
The issue, as complicated as it is, is made even

more so because federal law mandating retirement
at age 70 as been struck down. Universities, though
trying to gain permanent exemption from the law,
were granted a seven year exemption only. This
means as of 1994, professors can not be made to
retire on account of age.
The commitments to university-tenured faculty,
by means of employee retirement benefits, office
space etc., are significant. For good or bad, mandatory retirement ensured a certain rate of turnover
of professors. Hopkins is concerned that the lifting
of the law, by extending the high end of faculty age,
and tenuring associate professors, by extending the
low end of faculty age, will pinch the institution
financially and physically. All of this is beside its
concern about reducing the standard of professors.
To respond to the implicit danger of life-long
tenure, the University is considering periodic non
age-related evaluation of faculty, or hiring by contracts. Both of these are novel and worriesome
solutions.
Finding the best solution to these problems will
not be easy. The Academic Council is well-advised,
however, to carefully consider what standards are
used for the granting of tenure. Furthermore, it cannot relax its commitment to tenured faculty and must
reassert this commitment while the tenuous issue
of their future is being discussed.

A Semester's Tidings
It was not a thrilling semester for the Hopkins
newspaper business. It lacked firebombings or shanty arrests, university bond issues, fraternity newsletters, or even WJHU power boosts.
In fact, the biggest story of the semester was not
even a story in itself. The report of the Human
Climate Task Force Committee, while a substancial document, is really only important as it can
serve as a catalyst for reform and change.
Homewood, however, is by no means at a standstill. The construction continues, the money comes
in through the Campaign, plans are moving for student housing renovations and athletic center additions and a self-evaluation by the Arts and Sciences
and Engineering academic departments is (over)due
to begin.
All of this is exciting. But frustration tinges this
excitement. These projects and others will take
time—time short in the University's history perhaps,

but long in terms of an undergraduate career. To
be concerned at all requires looking beyond one's
own career. Concern manifests the affection one has
for the alma mater, and maybe a little well-wishing
for future undergraduates.
So undergraduates hope, with guarded optimism,
that the results of today's efforts pay off. Maybe
this sort of thing has been around as long as there
have been institutions with a future to look foward
to. Something feels different about Homewood now,
however. It feels like the plans are more numerous
than a couple of years ago. It also feels like there
is a new enhanced receptivity to undergraduate concerns. We can only hope that this is true. Also, we
can give our input and make improvements.
The item of our biggest news story concretized
some directions for the University to move. The
stage is set for great developments—the stuff of better universities, and better newspaper reading.

In a mournful November News-Letter issue oflast
year, the Editor decided, in what psychological state
of desperation we dare not guess, to reprint an
editorial from 1958. After vowing, with a certain
degree of indignation, never to do the same, we
humbly print thefollowingfrom the Christmas issue
of that same academic year. We reached the inescapable conclusion that it isfunny—uproariously
so—and it provides a look at what we actually do
here all of the time. Enjoy, and Happy Holidays.
We paced the filthy tiles of our private inner sanctum occupied in our favorite frivolity, the weekly
hate session. It usually takes the better part of the
evening, but as stated by an editor emeritus, "but
then we hate a lot of people." Our pupils dilated
and gleamed, fangs glistened, editorial venom oozed
over pallid jowls. "Hate" bellowed the News
Editor; "despise" hissed the Managing Editor; "a
pox upon thee" whispered the shy, but intrepid, cub
reporter. "You're coming along well stripling,"
remarked the Copy Editor to the cub. "Just put a
bit more vigor in it."
The Editors-in-Chief groveled for a three syllable
exclamation of abhorrence. "Execration," screeched one; "Acrimony" howled his cohort. They
grasped hands firmly and retired to their dungeon
to munch zweiback and to contemplate the editorial
navel.

"Nothing" uttered the Associate Editor in utter
amazement. "I just can't find a soul to hate this
week." "Nothing": it drifted from mouth to mouth;
it reverberated through the cobwebbed walls; it fell
upon the quivering ears of the household lords, who
dashed their crumbling zweiback to the floor and
rushed into the sanctum. All heads were bowed. The
Sports Editor spoke. "Oh, great pale paters, we can
find no one to hate."
"But you must!" saithed the lords, grabbing their
Davy Crockett bull whips.
Suddenly upon this midnight dreary a miniature
sleigh and eight tiny reindeer screeched upon the
sanctum roof, and plummeted in a sorry heap
through the rotted boards.
"Rather messy," said the News Editor, "but it
does look like a miniature sleigh and eight tiny
reindeer.
"I'm lost," said the driver.
"He broke our roof," screamed the Copy Editor.
"I'm cold now," bellowed the Associate Editor.
"He crushed our zweiback crumbs," hissed the
household lords. "Hate, hate, hate," floated
through the sanctum, caressed the curari case,
fondled the leather-bound edition of the complete
works of Machiavelli.
Venison has a slightly gamey flavor.

Music: The times, they are a changin'
by Phil Gochenour
The British punk movement of
the late seventies provided a vehicle for many bands that have present day popularity—The Clash,
Iggy Pop, and U2, to name just
a few. But what is also apparent
is that many of these groups have
had to undergo many changes
from their punk beginnings in
order to gain present-day
popularity.
One such group is The Alarm.
Starting off around 1977, The
Alarm came in on the very beginnings of the Punk movement, and
incorporated the fierce guitar
ferocity of the times with a rootsy,, acoustic-guitar/harmonica
style of music (later to be called
cowpunk) that was vaguely
reminiscent of such folk artists as
Bob Dylan. Also like Dylan,
these were four guys with
something to say. While most
punk bands of the time were content to say that the world sucked,
a statement that pop-critic Lester
Bangs described as being
"somewhat, ah, insufficient,"
The Alarm were busy making the
statement that the world sucked,
but if you stood up for and believed in yourself, and if we all hung
together, things mightn't
necessarily get better, but life
sure would be a lot more
tolerable. Such was the message
of their first two albums, The
Stand (an EP) and Declaration.
With their third album,
Strength, it was clear from the
opening synthesizer sequencing
_ of the first track, "Knife Edge,"
that some changes were in the air.
All four tracks of the first side
smacked of an attempt at AOR
radio airplay, and while songs
such as "Spirit of 76" and
"Deeside" still had the quality of
anthems, it seemed clear that the
folksy-guitar sound had been
traded for a slicker, more poporiented sound.
With their new album, Eye of
the Hurricane, it is clear that the
angry young men who started out
have mellowed a bit. Aside from
Dave Sharp's "One Step Closer
to Home," there is nothing that
resembles the earlier two albums,
either in terms of tone or musical
style. In a recent phone interview
with guitarist and co-songwriter
Eddie MacDonald, I asked him
about some of the changes the
band seems to have gone through,
and here's what he said.
What I wanted to talk about today was the new album and some
ofthe changes the hand has gone
through over the pastfew years.
It seems that the angry young
cowpunks of The Stand and
Declaration have mellowed out
and started writing love songs. Is
this indicative ofsome changes in
the band itself?
Well, I don't really recognize
labels for the group. The group
has gone through a period of five
or six years and our writing has
matured into its present-day
form. That's about all I can say
for that situation.
Well, when you first started out
in the band, what were some of

the things you had in mindfor it,
what were some of your goals?
Basically, I'm from a very
small town, a very working-class
background, and I enjoyed playing music. I fell in love with
music at a very early age, and I
wanted to get involved. I found
that the punk movement was a
very good way of getting started.

democracy. To some, [the election of

The Future of Tenure
The issue of tenure is a delicate, and above all,
complex one. It reflects the university's commitment to its immeasurably valuable recourse: the
faculty.
The Academic Council of the Homewood Schools
at present is attempting to redefine policy towards
granting tenure to associate professors. Two years
ago, the Council changed policy from not giving
associate professors tenure to giving it in "...exceptional circumstances where it is in the compelling interest of the University to do so..." The Council feels this policy is too vaguely worded to adequately guide them in tenure decisions.
The disposition to change policy two years ago
was motivated by a perception that associate professors were being lured to other institutions which
were offering associate professorships with tenure.
Recognizing certain problems with regualarly offering tenure to associate professors, they struck
upon the "exceptional circumstance" compromise.
The new policy, as Muller described "has caused more problems than it has solved." Proposals
to rectify the situation include granting tenure to
associate professors as a separate process from promotion to the rank of associate professor, and
regualarly granting associate profesoors tenure except in some circumstances.
The issue, as complicated as it is, is made even

more so because federal law mandating retirement
at age 70 as been struck down. Universities, though
trying to gain permanent exemption from the law,
were granted a seven year exemption only. This
means as of 1994, professors can not be made to
retire on account of age.
The commitments to university-tenured faculty,
by means of employee retirement benefits, office
space etc., are significant. For good or bad, mandatory retirement ensured a certain rate of turnover
of professors. Hopkins is concerned that the lifting
of the law, by extending the high end of faculty age,
and tenuring associate professors, by extending the
low end of faculty age, will pinch the institution
financially and physically. All of this is beside its
concern about reducing the standard of professors.
To respond to the implicit danger of life-long
tenure, the University is considering periodic non
age-related evaluation of faculty, or hiring by contracts. Both of these are novel and worriesome
solutions.
Finding the best solution to these problems will
not be easy. The Academic Council is well-advised,
however, to carefully consider what standards are
used for the granting of tenure. Furthermore, it cannot relax its commitment to tenured faculty and must
reassert this commitment while the tenuous issue
of their future is being discussed.

was the night I tried to go to sleep
when there was a Chem test the
next month. He has always admonished me to the fact that I, being a Humanities major, would be
working the Whopper board until the Burger King mandatory
retirement age of sixty-five, while
he would be raking in ten thou per
heart operation. I never did, and
still do not, agree that his choice
of goals is better than mine. For
while I now have the opportunity to do whatever I want in the
world, he is locked up for years
in med school, etc., etc. He may
be making $500,000 when he is
thirty, and I might be a struggling reporter for the Des Moines
Tractor Daily, but I think I will
have had the edge. For he might
wake up at age thirty and say,
"My God, what have I missed?"
One thing I have learned being
in this intensely pre-professional
environment is that the ceaseless
pursuit of success can only be
harmful to a person in the long
run. Life is, of course, for living.
I can only suggest that those of us
who feel an intense desire to zip
off to business school right after
graduation, and then on to a nice
paying desk job with E.F. Hutton, should stop and re-evaluate
their priorities. This is (discounting Budhist or Hari Krishna
beliefs) the only life you get. If
you don't experience all that you
can now, you never will again.
There is a professor of mine
who, although this is the first
semester I have had a class with
him, I have gotten to know fairly

well since being on a school trip
with him two years ago. As he
sits, at age thirty, and watches an
endless succesion of his grad
school friends settle down into
permanent jobs and get married,
I can sense a bit of uncomfortable
feelings in him. Every time
another friend gets married, he
- seems to feel the need to rationalize his independence and his
position in life by saying "My life
is different from these guys."
Perhaps he feels uncomfortable
with the fact that his life is not an
ordinary one. But I ask the question, "What is a 'normal' life??"
Is it right to settle down and get
a good career-oriented job at age
twenty-two just because everyone
else is, and that is what is expected of you? The moral of the
story is that I feel everyone must
decide what his or her priorities
are in life, while remembering
that you only go through once.
Anyway, I have rambled on
about nothing long enough. I just
want to say farewell to Hopkins
forever. So long. It has been nice.
Brad and Liz really are nice people. Winston still attends Med
School at Stanford. Jim Clancy is
still a dude and one half at Law
School. Seilers still is the chintziest organization on campus.
The Van Service is still abused.
My dog Bear is still the greatest
canine that ever lived. My sister,
now almost 25 (can you believe
it????) sends her regards.
Oh yeah. One last point. My
roommate Mike and I came up
with a good theme for a future
Spring Fair, based on the current
interest in the Vietnam War. We
envision the title of Back in the
'Nam, with the main features being the strewing of land mines
and punji pits on the lower quad,
free helicopter rides for all, and
maybe even a dunking booth over
a leech pool. What do you think,
Mary Ellen?
Bye Bye.

a few. But what is also apparent
is that many of these groups have
had to undergo many changes
from their punk beginnings in
order to gain present-day
popularity.
One such group is The Alarm.
Starting off around 1977, The
Alarm came in on the very beginnings of the Punk movement, and
incorporated the fierce guitar
ferocity of the times with a rootsy,, acoustic-guitar/harmonica
style of music (later to be called
cowpunk) that was vaguely
reminiscent of such folk artists as
Bob Dylan. Also like Dylan,
these were four guys with
something to say. While most
punk bands of the time were content to say that the world sucked,
a statement that pop-critic Lester
Bangs described as being
"somewhat, ah, insufficient,"
The Alarm were busy making the
statement that the world sucked,
but if you stood up for and believed in yourself, and if we all hung
together, things mightn't
necessarily get better, but life
sure would be a lot more
tolerable. Such was the message
of their first two albums, The
Stand (an EP) and Declaration.
With their third album,
Strength, it was clear from the
opening synthesizer sequencing
_ of the first track, "Knife Edge,"
that some changes were in the air.
All four tracks of the first side
smacked of an attempt at AOR
radio airplay, and while songs
such as "Spirit of 76" and
"Deeside" still had the quality of
anthems, it seemed clear that the
folksy-guitar sound had been
traded for a slicker, more poporiented sound.
With their new album, Eye of
the Hurricane, it is clear that the
angry young men who started out
have mellowed a bit. Aside from
Dave Sharp's "One Step Closer
to Home," there is nothing that
resembles the earlier two albums,
either in terms of tone or musical
style. In a recent phone interview
with guitarist and co-songwriter
Eddie MacDonald, I asked him
about some of the changes the
band seems to have gone through,
and here's what he said.
What I wanted to talk about today was the new album and some
ofthe changes the hand has gone
through over the pastfew years.
It seems that the angry young
cowpunks of The Stand and
Declaration have mellowed out
and started writing love songs. Is
this indicative ofsome changes in
the band itself?
Well, I don't really recognize
labels for the group. The group
has gone through a period of five
or six years and our writing has
matured into its present-day
form. That's about all I can say
for that situation.
Well, when you first started out
in the band, what were some of

the things you had in mindfor it,
what were some of your goals?
Basically, I'm from a very
small town, a very working-class

music at a very early age, and I
wanted to get involved. I found
that the punk movement was a

couldn't play to get in and learn
how to play. We formed The
Alarm because we found
ourselves in the situation in our
hometown where there were very
few outlets. I had no qualifications, in school I really didn't fit
into the educational system, and
music was my one way of selfexpression, really.

that have occurred because of
that have helped you in getting to
where you are now?

feel you're doing now? How was
the band changedfrom when you
started out with the punk
movement?
(Long pause.) Like all
movements.. . what it did was encourage me, basically, from the
word go. It managed, I would
say, to move the group on. I find
it a difficult question to answer,
actually, it's a bit awkward.
Maybe you can express it another
way.
Okay, let's put it this way.
What's the band trying to accomplish now, what are your
present-day goals?

essentially. That's basically it, I
don't want to sound too pompous.
People say we make music with
a message, music with a conscience. I make music with a love.
I love music, and I always have.

be the ideal sort of thing for The
Alarm, the ultimate median.
But the message you started out
with seems to have changed
somewhat. Songs like "Marching
On seem radically differentfrom
things like "In the Presence of
Love. It seems that there is
much less of the fight and more
ofan emphasis on relationships.
Well, I believe if you're going
to write a great song, you only
write it once, you don't try and
repeat it. "Marching On" is still
as relevant today as when it was
written. I don't believe in blunting out a great song through
repetition. "Presence of Love" is
a song in its own right. It was
written with the basis of the group
going through a shift late last
year, early this year. We basically had to close the door on the
music business after the Strength
album. There was an awful lot of
pressure on the group to follow
a pattern, to release another
album quickly and capitalize on
everything we'd achieved before,
and we were determined not to
fall into those sorts of traps, trying to make music just to be commercially successful. So we had-

to make music in our own time,

rhythms, really. You start to

you'd gone too hardfor numbers

something for yourselves?

myself. I enjoy making music,
and I find albums very difficult to
make, because it's an emotional
thing and so much effort goes into making them. But with this

a bit more and just basically enjoy it. I can talk for myself on that

dissatisfaction with Strength, you
chose to build upon the style of

your earlier style.

songs and treated each song with
the respect that it deserves, and
that's all I can really say on that
one. Because when you write a
song, you have a certain feel in
mind. I rather go by the feel of
the song rather than what the style
of the current climate of production is, or the climate of what we
did on the last album. We have
our own musical style, our own
way we approach things. But
basically, we just go by what suits
the song. The song is the cornerstone of everything. really.

in six weeks and mixed it in six
weeks. I just wish that nowadays
albums could be made in about
two weeks. It's a shame really,

Do you think one ofthe reasons

more production value into it?
Six weeks? (laughs) I think that
answers that question.

curiosity. As I was looking at the
